description: For me personally, this app is better than vlc player. I used vlc player for a year & I got so much frustration. It glitch when I pause and play back but this player doesn't have that kind of glitch and It is very light weight. Very good.
The Best Player for Linux with Amazing Design
I love this player.
Shortcuts for all functions are present and lightweight too.

It's very light weight. Getting used to it may take some reading but it's worth it. The youtube-dl integration is a cherry on top. You can watch videos from websites without the performance hit of a fat browser trying to do it in JS. That's very good for lightweight machines.
Baically the fastest and least cluttered video player with tons of features out there, and not only in GNU/Linux world. Although Wayland support is still somewhat limited due to some bugs.
My minimalistic needs have been satisfied. Oh joy. It's perfect.
Everything is great.
The best player, very fast with a GUI friendly.
The only player i use, i was tired of the look of VLC but it was the best video player until i have found MPV which can read any video format and is beautiful too!

Found this after it was impossible to get VLC to work.

- VLC would open one window for audio and one for video.
- VLC would make the screen go clack every few minutes unless I was moving my mouse( I didn't have screen locking or screen saver mode on, and I tried every last piece of **** evidence I could find online. Still never stopped).
- VLC would also never quit and it was impossible to close it in the KSysGuard System Monitor app, I had to kill i through the terminal.
- All the stress of trying to fix bugs with VLC was causing stress, hair loss and the development of a heart problems.

- mpv Media Player has none of these problems.
- It plays any encoding, and has all the options and buttons you need in a lightweight easy to use interface. No extra BS options that you'll never ever use.
It just works!

Thank you!
summary: Everything you need, nothing you don't

description: No bloat, no crashing, and supports all the latest video rendering technology under the hood using a .config file.

This thing did not even begin to work on a late 2018 version of Debian.
Launching the thing gave me a black rectangle that I could resize and close. There was no way to load any video at all.
A true unsong hero in video playback where more popular players can't compare to how gracefully MPV operates.

The playback is fine, but apart from that, it's horrible:
I made it fullscreen and it "stole" my keyboard input, locking me in
- Escape key did nothing
- ALT + F4 did nothing
- Alt + Tab did nothing
- Windows key did nothing

There was no GUI or keyboard way to leave fullscreen mode.
I skipped ahead until the video ended but the window was still open and my desktop visible, my keyboard was still stolen, and my KDE theme's transparency was broken. Couldn't find the process in task manager. Had to CTRL + ALT + TAB and logout then back in, and that resolved the issue.
There is no GUI method to change volume, can only mute, to change volume one has to use hotkeys.

I would rate this -5 stars if I could!

The only reason I don't uninstall this is because it will then uninstall SMPlayer, which actually works.
Skip this, just sudo apt install smplayer
Lightweight, no rubbish and takes just about anything you throw at it, all around great stuff!
not bad its notbad
light weight awesome app
Fastest player ever.

Best player for Linux imo. Fast, simple and clean and plays anything you through at it.
This is my default media app using Gnome for the first time and loving it. If you find less to be more this is player is most definitely for you.
Works as it should be! More smooth and beautiful picture with properly anti-aliasing without additional settings from the box.
Easy to use simple app that fires right up and just works!!
I absolutely hate it, literally no playback controls.
summary: Why is this a default app?

description:
Minimalist player - no menu that I could find - that "just works" ;D Plays (mkv) subtitles, multiple audio streams, chapters and skipping forward/back with the arrow keys. Simple. 
Does not support multiple video streams (heh!) because it simply lacks the controls.

+ Plays 4K HEVC with hardware acceleration (Nvidia drivers, Ubuntu 19) - VLC does it in software
+ No screen tearing! - which was a major advertising point and the reason for installing it. How it does it I don't know - not by framerate doubling, apparently.

And the picture really looks pretty nice, so 5/5.
No problems on my 2007 built Toshiba Satellite A200 with Lubuntu 18.04
Absolutely no control whatsoever. You drag and drop files onto it to make it play them. It cannot work from a library so it is completely useless for most cases especially TV series.
Hardware decoding and AV1 support through libdav1d. Config file offers very nice options. OSD codec info

The only one that reliably works everywhere, whether Mac, Windows or Linux. Has to be the Deb version like this and not th Snap version though.

This uses the MPlayer engine that is the core of the vast majority of Players, but no fancy GUI stuff going on. Whatever OS I set up, MPV goes on them all. Always works with whatever you throw at it. Something VLC can't claim. Try playing Transport Stream with VLC and MPV and it's a no-brainer, MPV wins out every time.
Pretty cool, it allows you to listen (or watch) videos from youtube without opening the browser and killing your ram. The gui is minimal and it should be used with the shortcut (q to quit).
Plays everything

plays all kind of video without a single lag or stuff .
works better than vlc player. vlc often cracks the audio makes it annoying . this works pretty good no cracking. yeah it worth 5 stars.

description: VLC had screen tearing and lots of horizontal lines like on old screens. MPV has none of that and additionally can play many URLs you throw at it thanks to youtube-dl.
goooooooooooooood
Not playing m3u files any more.

minimal. works great from a terminal emulator in a GNU/Linux environment.

has a text configuration file in your /home/user/.config/mpv/ directory, or you can make one and write you configuration preferences inside. don't forget to save it when you're done.

look for Celluloid if you need a more 'complete' GTK front-end interface.

used VLC for years but MPV/Celluloid works better for ME.

I've used VLC for years on both Windows and Linux and after using mpv for a couple of years I've come to the conclusion that this has to be the best mediaplayer. The ability to play almost anything, from files to urls without going to different submenues and still being relativly lightweight makes this undoubtly better than VLC. While the shortcuts may always make sence I certainly love that they are there, and you can always rebind them in the config file. The scripts are also a really nice addition to the program. In short. This is the best mediaplayer out there.
summary: Simply the best mediaplayer out there

description: Tiny and supports a lot of codecs. Rich functionality available from commandline interface.

Ich kenne keinen schnelleren Videospieler. Ist an sich aber nur auf Tastatureingaben getrimmt. Linksklick verschiebt bei mir das Fenster, Rechtklick pausiert. Binds können in einer Config festgelegt werden, Standards sind in den man-pages (`man mpv`).

bester player für mp3s und videos nicht so überladen wie andere player, hoffe das irgendwan noch ein paar funktionen hinzu kommen, wie schwarzer balken entfernen und lautstärke fest ein stellen kann.
Sehr Gut, spielt alles ab (VLC hat probleme beim hevc DVB aufnahmen). Man muss auch das Video nicht vorher stoppen um den Player zu schliessen, wie beim VLC (sonst hängt sich VLC auf).
Spielt sehr viele Formate ab, läuft flüssig und ist auch noch frei und open source! Kann ich nur empfehlen.
summary: Viele Funktionen und auch noch FOSS
